segments.text: So with the innovation program, they had a thing called the TIG, Technology Innovation Group.
And the thrust of this was to try to develop new technologies.
And as it turned out, this focused largely on computer technology in all the cities.
and waste disposal technologies and stuff like that.
And we had I don't know how many cities we eventually worked with.
I think it was something between 50 and 60 cities in the state of Texas.
In addition to that, we had, through the NSF program, we created a backup agency to help
Little Rock, Arkansas, and Boulder, Colorado.
So it was a tremendously successful program.
And then in the, what, about 76, I guess it was, then we hired Don Moore, who replaced me as the director of the center.
And of course it went on up until the early 80s, and the federal funding report disappeared, and things went downhill pretty rapidly.
It was a separate center at that time, and I had nothing to do with it.
And then the HUD support
dried up and NSF support dried up.
And I guess, to me, one of the saddest elements of that whole thing was that the cities wouldn't support us.
And I guess I shouldn't have been too surprised at that, but I was.
We had, over the decade of the 70s or the last half of it,
We had developed, I thought, excellent rapport with the cities.
They're very applied in their concerns.
And you have to be careful about the words that you use in working with them.
For example, we learned rather quickly, you don't say research.
Because when you say research, a city councilman in Abilene or whatever will conjure up some guy in a white coat surrounded by test tubes.
And they're not interested in funding anyone, so we called it property-solving.
But in spite of that, and in spite of the fact that we had done, I thought, a hell of a lot of good things for the cities, Don Moore, and there was never a more able guy,
Don Moore was just unable to draw any support from Texas cities to continue that.
And when Dr. Porter took over TEAS, his edict was, if it can't be self-supporting, I'm not interested in supporting it.
And I think it's wrong of you, frankly, but because this still is a land grant college, I think we still have
duty to help the people of the state of Texas, and I think that's one of the things that we've done.

But I went to him when the Center was essentially given, the program operation was essentially given back to me with a recommendation that put some T's money into it to keep it going, because I thought that the federal funding would eventually swing the pendulum and swing back the other way.
And there would be money coming.
I've seen these oscillations within the federal staff before, and I thought it would occur again.
But Skip wasn't interested in that.
And with his background, I didn't understand that.
So although it still exists on paper,
And we still do a few little things.
A couple of years ago, we did some things for the City of Edinburgh in South Texas.
And so we still have that thrust.
But as you're aware, there is now a new center for affairs set up, which incidentally draws on some of the faculty that were involved with us in the Old Urban Program Center.
And that's great.
I think it's nice to have that.
The problem it will have is that there is no keys involved, so they won't have any.
And so they're going to be scraping along with what they can.
and of course some of the liberal arts faculty and others are empowered to use some of their academic time for research.
It's different than it is here at the Tees, of course.
We want to do research, so we have to invest in one.
But over there, professors are given
release time from their teaching chores to do research.
And so they can do, you know, they can do some things.
So there are some guys in liberal arts that want to do that work with the cities.
There are a couple, three guys in business administration.
And, of course, Rossler in urban planning and architecture.
And these are the same people, at least the same organizations that we have involved in the arts of the city.
So in any event, that was too much detail, I'm sure, on the Center for Integral Arts.
I hadn't really gotten enough on that chapter or something.
It was a fascinating time, fascinating experience.
The Center for Strategic Technology, how did that come about?
Oh, my land.
How many more takes did you have?
How much time did you have?
We got another hour.
Hours were a thing.
Oh, my.
Do you want the full story on that?
I guess so.
Well... Is this your idea?
I'm sorry?
Is this your idea?
Oh, yeah.
Yeah, I guess.
Again, coupled with Mr. Benson.
He deserves credit.
Um... Well...
I guess the original ideas sprang from some things that began to occur in the mid-70s.
I think the first time we started even verbalizing, he and I, notions that gradually over a period of time
shape themselves into what is now the center.
I guess that was probably late 74 and mid-75.
And the thrust of it was the following.
It was clear that Texas A&M aspired to greatness.
It wants to be a great university.
And it was also clear that, you know, as I've already said, back in the 50s it was a great educational institution.
But it was a kind of insular sort of, had very limited viewpoints, very limited outlook and outreach.
And of course, as the research program was started by Mr.
Rudder and Mr. Parson, it flowered.
And of course, that outreach effort expanded.
And our worldly awareness, if you will, expanded.
And there was also a realization that every great news, again, if you look at MIT and Stanford and Telecom, what makes them great?
Well, as we've already said, it's not their academic programs.
It's part of the old graduate programs, but certainly not undergraduate programs.
And research programs, yeah.
But more than that, they apply their expertise to solve problems that are sort of like the old RAIN program, problems that are associated with national needs.
So, and it also helps to have people appointed to high places.
So you see Henry Kissinger come in from Harvard, and the Secretaries of Defense from MIT and Stanford.
And that helps the image of greatness.
And what this all boiled down to was that we wanted to try to insert Texas A&M
more into national and international affairs, more into attacking the great problems of our time, if you want to be that grandiose about it.
And it was just felt that in addition to having a damn good academic program, undergraduate and graduate, in addition to having a damn good research program, we wanted to do more.
we wanted to insert ourselves into some of the national decision-making processes.
And I remember writing Mr. Benson a memo back in, I think, 75, where I told him I was concerned about Texas A&M's image as, I think my words were, a football, military-oriented Cal College.
an image that to some extent was deserved, but to a large extent was not deserved.
And that I thought we needed to have a, I just called it a special research program, that would be aimed at dispelling that image and creating a new image.
And so I told him some notions I had about how to proceed with this.
He, I told him that as I surveyed the faculty that was appropriate to this effort, and this has to be guys, I mean these have to be faculty members who have national or international reputation.
People that were sort of like E.F. Hutton, you know, when they taught folks, listen, we didn't have them.
within the College of Engineering.
I could count them, again, on the things of my family.
And so I told him that I thought we ought to get some money from our affluent graduates, Mr. Sackler and others.
We always were Mr. Sackler.
We always needed money, and he always used it.
And I thought we ought to get a little bundle of cash.
Well, maybe not such a little bundle.
And we ought to go by people, people that have clout, people that have international expertise.
And it doesn't take many.
You need some sort of critical mass.
I mean, one guy's not going to make it, but three or four, yeah.
Again, if they were working in complementary areas, you couldn't have a guy here and another guy there.
To some extent, I'm here walking teeth.

and uh well in any event that was the thrust of that memo and he thought that was great and so he marched promptly over to the dr williams office laid it on him and dr williams thought it was great but he said it needs to be focused well over the next uh next few weeks and months he focused it
And it now exists as the Center for Free Enterprise Research and Education.
And I'll never forget the day that that decision was made that it was going to be given to economics.
Mr. Benson came into my office with a characteristic full of esteem, and he was livid.
And kind of as a sop, why,
Dr. Williams had put Mr. Madison on the Board of Advisors or something like that.
And don't misunderstand.
We couldn't fault and do not fault the thrust of that Senate.
It is a very worthwhile thing to do, and it's a job that needs to be done, and it should be pursued.
should be pursued more aggressively, frankly, than I think it was pursued right now.
But nonetheless, that operation sort of missed the target that we had originally identified.
And so during, that was set up about, what, 76, I think, or maybe 77, I can't remember.
But over that next year,
I can remember Mr. Benson would go to these meetings of that board of advisors, and he would come back boiling every time.
And because, again, it was sort of our idea that had been perverted.
And so by 1977 then,
He and I had agreed that we were going to make another run.
Of course, we had a new administration at that time, and Dr. Williams was out of the scene, out of the picture, and Garvey was going to have been taken over.
And then some other interesting things began to happen in 1977.
we had begun to talk with various government people about this idea, and trying to get them to help us shape the thing.
And so we were visited in 77 by some fairly high-ranking Air Force men, and they said that
You know, we need a new think tank, a new defense-related think tank to do several things.

But the reason we need a new one is that most of the existing think tanks have become too institutionalized, or as they put it, one Air Force officer said, they have become so much a part of the Washington scene
that they have begun to feed on, and we're not getting any fresh things out in any time.
We need a think tank that will do Soviet studies, because a lot of our Soviet, existing Soviet studies are too much based on the mirror image syndrome, and what that means is that
a philosophical viewpoint which looks at the Soviets as mirror images of us, that fundamentally they're just like us.
They think like us.
They want the same things in the world as we do.
They respond to pressures in the world as we do.
Of course, that's just not true.
But it did, and I did my first Soviet piece of Soviet work back in 1942.
before I went back to Ohio State for graduate work.
And so I've seen the mirror image syndrome in action, and it was exactly right.
Because I remember thinking that myself when I was young and ignorant.
And so they then suggested that this new center, that we had still somewhat ill-formed in our
ought to have a very definite national security thrust to it.
And so that was reflected in the way the Senate was finally shaped.
But if you look at our charter, you will find that we are empowered to look at energy systems, transportation systems, urban systems.
Mr. Benson, bless his heart, fought with the center out and did all kinds of great things.
And indeed, in the first year of our operation, we were focused, we had a fairly broad focus.
And incidentally, he was, was and is of the opinion that the state of Texas
sort of lurches from crisis to crisis without any long-range planning.
And so the center's charter states that we will do strategic studies for the state of Texas, long-range planning studies for the state of Texas.
An incredibly broad charter.
Here again, it's sort of, and he gave us some money to get it started, of course.
And he
And he had his characteristic viewpoint about this.
But he knew we were tackling, we were trying to slay a much larger dragon.
And here, he said, you have that thing self-supporting for 10 years.
And that's what it would have taken to have functioned the way we had originally started.
So it was really with that charter that he took to the Board of Regents in the spring of 78.
And I'd been a visiting professor over at the American University in Cairo.
And we didn't even have a name for the damn thing at that time, at least that we had settled on.
And I remember when I was still in Cairo,
We telexed back and forth, and he had some other name for it.
And I remember telexing him and telling him that it ought to be called the Center for Strategic Technology.
And so that was the name that went forth to the Board of Regents.
But he talked about the input we'd had from the Air Force officers and the national security issues.
He told them that it was our intention to do classified work.
It was our intention to work with the intelligence agencies.
Well, can you imagine going to the Board of Regents of Berkeley, UC Berkeley, with a proposal like that?
Never in Christ's name.
But with the rich military traditions,
And so we set about building yet another new program.
And then, of course, one year into that, Mr. Manson retired and Dr. Porter took over.
Again, Dr. Porter wasn't interested in long-term payoff.
His directive to me was make it self-supporting as quickly as you can.
And he said, I'll give you three years.
He didn't say that specifically, but that was the message that I got.
Well, the place where there is money is DOD.
And so we focused our efforts
almost totally that opportunity.
And we were self-supporting it for years.
Again, starting from scratch, starting with no credibility.
And again, you know, even though the program took some turns that were not originally envisioned, it couldn't have happened without Teasman.
And so now we bring in about a million bucks a year.
We have about a million dollars a year.
Of that, I get $90,000 from teams.
And the rest of it is hustle.
And I think as of the 1st of August, the center will be five years old.
And we've had a fair amount of success.
But again, it all starts with T's.
Now, the center's focus has merit, right?
Because of funding?
Temporarily, yes.
But it is my intention to broaden it as I can.
So once you've got one area financially solvent, so...
Right.
and then get T's money to broaden that to New York?
Well, I don't know that we can get T's money to New York.
I did get a, this next year they will give me $120,000.
And I intend to use that additional $30,000 to try to broaden that.
One of my colleagues, Dr. Bragg,

is now interacting with the governor's office and that's a very very slow process but but we are trying to pursue this responsibility that we have to do some advanced planning for the state we have had a couple little things we did an incredible study for the state of texas and see the when the center was formed
Mr. Bradley had left the Industrial Economics Research Division to take over TEKS.
And so that was brought in to the Center for Strategic Technology.
Again, the thought being that that could be the focus for our state efforts.
And if we'd had a little bit more
But the economic development, industrial development monies began to dry up.
And so we've lost most of the people that populated that effort.
And as a matter of fact, Dr. Bragg, I guess, is the only one that's left.
But yes, we will
try to live up to the charter that was originally described for the center.
And I think our defense program is in relatively good shape now, and it's just a question of doing the necessary promotion and establishing credibility to get involved in these other areas.
And I think we can do it.
You talk about interdisciplinary work problems.
Mostly you're dealing with engineering, but in this center you have to go outside of engineering.
Is that a bigger problem, or is it pretty much the same as just getting engineers to work?
Oh, it's basically the same problem there, but it's...
It has a little bit different connotation to it, a little bit different complexion to it, I guess I should say.
Yeah, you're right.
We have had in the center, in this center, people from folks in sociology working for us right now.
We've had people from history,
from business administration, one guy from architecture, and a few from engineering.
The problems we encounter in that are, well, we still have this problem of
Say we have a person from sociology who's going to work for us.
Well, okay, suppose he or she comes over and just does some really outstanding work for us.
I can't affect their promotion.
Their promotion is handled through the sociology department.
So the only damn thing I can do, do-do,

is to, in the fall of the year, when tenure and promotion concerns are operational, I write the dean and the department head of the appropriate college and department head and give them an accounting of how that person has performed.
And that's the most I can do.
So I guess that's the most difficult problem we have.
The other problem deals with classified work.
And here again, you have to assess the attitude of the dean and department head in question.
If they want a young man or a young woman to publish, then you dastardly get them involved in classified work.
And so on those, when we encounter that situation, we've had a few circumstances.
There's a man in political science, whom I will not name, who has been interested in our work.
But I have had to take him aside and tell him, look,
getting involved with us may be hazardous to your academic health.
And of course in that case we have a department that is controlled not by the dean, not by the department head, but by a committee of four professors.
And none of whom are Soviet experts, none of whom give a flip for Soviet work.
And so
A young man ain't going to ride Soviet boat to promotion and tenure in that department because it has to be approved by the full press.

And so he has to be, in effect, a traitor to his own cause and go over the hurdles that they set up for him, namely, you know, you will do such and such kind of work, you will publish in this journal and that journal, but not in those, and you won't publish things through the Senate, which would be in the court, you know.
And so in that case, then, what we tend to do, we tend to do two things.
We will go to a tenured full professor who has all of these things and can tell the department head or the dean to go to him and get him involved.
And we have some of those.
Or we'll go outside.
If you walk across the hall, across the office area, you'll meet Dr. Jamie Kipp.
He's from Kansas State.
A historian.
Tremendous guy.
He's an expert on the Soviet Navy, an expert on the Soviet military, doing the Soviet Navy.
Incredible guy.
And he has, he has, we have a summer fellows program here.
Because many of these guys have nine months
And so he is here for his second summer.
And then we support him and his graduating students during the year.
This is with federal money.
And we've had Dr. Bill Fuller at the Harvard Russian Research Center.
Can you imagine Texas A&M sponsoring work at Harvard?
It happens.
Dr. Bill Zimmerman, the University of Michigan, Dr. Ivan Volkis, the University of Nebraska.
We will have two gentlemen from the Air Force Academy with us this summer for short stays.
He's going to Scotland.
Oh, Erickson.
Well, I wasn't...
He's not Summer Phillip, but that's a... That's a special case.
We have to talk about John.
But, you know, there's somebody else...
I don't know their U.S.
But in any event...
That's the general way we've solved that problem.
Now, let me pursue this, because it may be of interest to whomever is listening to this tape a hundred years from now.
Dr. Porter has suggested that we might go hire a full-time research
instead of using faculty to staff our research teams.
And he and I have had another rather serious disagreement over that.
And don't misunderstand me.
We just have different points of view here.
We're not wild-eyed enemies of one another.
I think we have a great deal of respect for one another.
But I have trouble with that.
because my view is if you're going to have full-time research people, then why the hell not have a Southwest Research Institute or a Battelle or whatever?

Or putting it the other way, my view is that anybody that our principal job as an institution is teaching still, and you can talk about the research program and you can talk about influencing national decision-making processes, but all of that ought to
impact the teaching and educational process, the intellectual development of the young people, because that's why we're here, first and fundamentally.
And so having a bunch of people that never see a student, never go into a classroom, I don't dig that at all.
I have great philosophical
But if we can't solve some of these other problems, if I can't get my hands on the faculty that I need, then what am I to do?
I guess I can either say, well, you know, we will attenuate the growth of the center to fit whatever we can draw on, or we can go out and have the answer.
Well, he and I had a rather serious discussion about that about six months ago.
And I was ready to submit my resignation letter because it was just philosophically not acceptable to me.
But we came to an accommodation.
And what we agreed was that as long as 50% of the program
would somehow impact the teaching function.
Fine.
When it gets to be 51%, that's when I leave.
So that's the interdisciplinary problem is a far reaching one.
It has a lot of impact, as you can see from this discussion.
And I don't know how to solve it.
Because certainly other colleges, other departments have different views.
And of course, there are those who think that the center is a wrong operation.
In other words, they will say, as soon as you take money from DOD, you're sold.
and I say, your ass is bought, that you're dancing to their tune.
Well, I suppose with some that may be true, but it's not true here.
And now it's true that DOD will tell us, they will give us money to do a specific piece of research.
I mean, they will give you, well, incredible as it may seem, I have got a little chunk of money
And the guy said, I asked him, I said, what do you want to do with it?
Is there anything you want to do with it?
Which is .
That's not strictly true.
It has to be related to space things, but within the space of anything that you want to do.
But most of it, most of them, all the rest of the money that we get out of it is specifically the record.
So they do specify the topics that we study, but they don't specify the way we do our research.
And above all, they don't specify the results of our research.
And I don't have any problem with that.
I don't think it restricts us at all.
So, but clearly if, and already because of the success we have had, Dr. Porter has asked me, how big is the center going to get?
How big do you want to be?
Because I think he perceives that we could probably be almost as big as we wanted to be.
And that's a good question.
I don't know.
My answer to him was a kind of a pat answer.
an evasive answer because I said to him that I want to be as big as we have to be to meet our service needs to Texas A&M.
And I don't really know what that is.
I don't know how many faculty might want to get involved with us.
when it comes to influence any national decision-making processes, I do want to insert Texas A&M into that process, into that whole business.
I want to see more Texas A&M faculty testifying before Congress.
When I was at Maryland, it just hurt me.
It still hurts me to go to Washington and when Congress needs expertise, and law would be not always, but most of the time will be some guy from MIT or Stanford, and that just gripes me badly.
And there are times when
when a southwestern viewpoint on certain national issues needs to be inserted.
And that's not to say that we've got all the right answers or anything.
But you know, we've, you know, back in 20 years ago, we had guys like Lyndon Johnson and John Connery and Holden Teague
and many others who represented this area.
Now, I wouldn't want to say that I supported those guys in everything they did or said, because I didn't.
On the other hand, they represented the area well.
They inserted
regional viewpoints into the national decision-making processes.
And now they're gone.
And Conley's still around, of course, but he's not influential anymore in the national sense.
And I think to some extent, we can't fill those shoes, but to some extent,
We ought to try.
I think one of the things we can do is to represent the people of the state of Texas in some of these matters.
And so I want us to pursue that as aggressively as we can.

Well, I've testified before Congress, but it's been a situation where I'm sitting here in the fold around a friend of mine in Washington who knew that I had certain kinds of expertise, would say, hey, Dick, could you come on and offer some testimony?
Yeah.
Well, that's a passive system.
And Aggies ain't passive.
We're active.
And so what I would like to do is to have a situation where we could understand
what was going on in Congress and the issues that they were going to be confronting.

When a certain area came up in which we had expertise, not here within the center, but within the college or within the university, that we could put a guy on an airplane and get him up there before Congress.
And that we could do research and do studies that would influence some of the actions.
So I don't know how big we're going to grow.
that clearly one way or another we are going to have to solve that problem of doing interdisciplinary work.
Because there aren't any of these issues that are narrowly focused.
They almost always involve a breadth of disciplines.
So somehow we've got to solve that problem.
Well, of course, Erickson deserves a lot of credit for the success that the cinema has had.
I first met John in 1979, just about the time that the cinema was formed.
I don't know how much you know about John Erickson.
Oh, I know a little to the history part.
Yeah, hopefully.
Well, he's, if you listed the top five or six Western criminologists or experts on the Soviet military, that he would have to be among them.
He's a brilliant man, a genius by any standard.
speaks six languages fully as a photographic memory.
Couldn't find his way through the DFW airport unaided if his life depended on it, you know, he's a thoroughgoing academician and just one public man.
The relationship with Erickson began
Really, it had its roots in the productivity program, if you believe.
I had been appointed to this Air Force oversight committee to look over the equipment for the whole program.
You see, the ICANN program, the manufacturing program.
And a young Air Force captain who was involved in that program lived next door to a guy who had been a member of the Colonel Lynn Kelsey.
who is on our staff here, but he is on Lynn.
And Lynn had been selected as an Air Force Research Associate and had spent a year with John over in Illinois.
And so, through this Air Force Captain, I got Lynn's name and he was in the Pentagon at that time and stopped by to see him.
And that led to John's visiting Texas A&M.
And then an interesting incident happened.
You know, you look at these things, dear, and you have to prove that somebody upstairs is looking out for you.
It's incredible how these things happen.
John has enjoyed support from the Pentagon for many years because of his incredible understanding of the Second Posture.
But of course the Pentagon cannot give money directly to a foreign institution.
And so it has to be laundered.
It has to be channeled through another organization.
And one of the
At that time, the organization was one of the important
